message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Local reasoning for Java
Paper Abstract: This thesis develops the local reasoning approach of separation logic for common forms of modularity such as abstract datatypes and objects. In particular, this thesis focuses on the modularity found in the Java programming language. We begin by developing a formal semantics for a core imperative subset of Java, Middleweight Java (MJ), and then adapt separation logic to reason about this subset. However, a naive adaption of separation logic is unable to reason about encapsulation or inheritance: it provides no support for modularity. First, we address the issue of encapsulation with the novel concept of an abstract predicate, which is the logical analogue of an abstract datatype. We demonstrate how this method can encapsulate state, and provide a mechanism for ownership transfer: the ability to transfer state safely between a module and its client. We also show how abstract predicates can be used to express the calling protocol of a class. However, the encapsulation provided by abstract predicates is too restrictive for some applications. In particular, it cannot reason about multiple datatypes that have shared read-access to state, for example list iterators. To compensate, we alter the underlying model to allow the logic to express properties about read-only references to state. Additionally, we provide a model that allows both sharing and disjointness to be expressed directly in the logic. Finally, we address the second modularity issue: inheritance. We do this by extending the concept of abstract predicates to abstract predicate families. This extension allows a predicate to have multiple definitions that are indexed by class, which allows subclasses to have a different internal representation while remaining behavioural subtypes. We demonstrate the usefulness of this concept by verifying a use of the visitor design pattern.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Separation logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_logic"},{"title":"Bunched logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunched_logic"},{"title":"Peter O'Hearn - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_O'Hearn"},{"title":"Dafny - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dafny"},{"title":"Separation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_theorem"},{"title":"Linear separability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linearly_separable"},{"title":"Presentation logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presentation_logic"},{"title":"Lusin's separation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lusin's_separation_theorem"},{"title":"Separation of concerns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_of_concerns"},{"title":"Axiom schema of specification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiom_schema_of_specification"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **Separation Logic**:

## Definition and Purpose

Separation logic is an extension of Hoare logic, a way of reasoning about programs. More specifically, separation logic is an extension of Hoare logic that facilitates reasoning about mutable data structures that use pointers.

## Key Contributors

It was developed by John C. Reynolds, Peter O'Hearn, Samin Ishtiaq and Hongseok Yang, drawing upon early work by Rod Burstall.

## Core Concept

Separation logic supports local reasoning, whereby specifications and proofs of a program component mention only the portion of memory used by the component, and not the entire global state of the system.

## Extensions and Applications

With Stephen Brookes, O'Hearn created Concurrent Separation Logic (CSL), extending the theory further.(no content)O'Hearn and Brookes are co-recipients of the 2016 Gödel Prize for their invention of Concurrent Separation Logic.

## Practical Tools

Facebook Infer is a static analysis tool for Java, C, and Objective-C based on separation logic and bi-abduction. Additionally, Dafny includes a variation of separation logic known as implicit dynamic frames for reasoning about side effects.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Abstract data type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_data_type"},{"title":"Set (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Stack (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Stream (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stream_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Collection (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collection_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"List (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Abstract graphical data type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_graphical_data_type"},{"title":"Graph (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Container (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Container_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Tree (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(abstract_data_type)"}]

## Abstract Data Type

An abstract data type (ADT) is a mathematical model for data types, defined by its behavior (semantics) from the point of view of a user of the data, specifically in terms of possible values, possible operations on data of this type, and the behavior of these operations.

### Key Characteristics

Formally, an ADT is analogous to an algebraic structure in mathematics, consisting of a domain, a collection of operations, and a set of constraints the operations must satisfy.(no content)The interface of the ADT typically refers only to the domain and operations, and perhaps some of the constraints on the operations, such as pre-conditions and post-conditions.

### History

ADTs were first proposed by Barbara Liskov and Stephen N. Zilles in 1974, as part of the development of the CLU language.(no content)The reason for introducing the notion of abstract data types was to allow interchangeable software modules.

### Common Examples

Some well-known abstract data types include:
- A stack, which serves as a collection of elements with two main operations: Push, which adds an element to the collection, and Pop, which removes the most recently added element.
- A set, which can store unique values, without any particular order.
- Lists also form the basis for other abstract data types including the queue, the stack, and their variations.

### Relationship to Programming

The notion of abstract data types is related to the concept of data abstraction, important in object-oriented programming and design by contract methodologies for software engineering.

Web search results for query: "Java programming language"

Links: [{"title":"Java (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Category:Java programming language family - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Java_programming_language_family"},{"title":"Talk:Java (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Java_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Outline of the Java programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_the_Java_programming_language"},{"title":"Self (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Mesa (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesa_(programming_language)"},{"title":"General-purpose programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General-purpose_programming_language"},{"title":"Smalltalk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smalltalk"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Java_(programming_language)/Selected_article"},{"title":"Talk:Java (programming language)/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Java_(programming_language)%2FArchive_1"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Java programming language:

## Overview

Java is a high-level, general-purpose, memory-safe, object-oriented programming language.(no content)It is intended to let programmers write once, run anywhere (WORA), meaning that compiled Java code can run on all platforms that support Java without the need to recompile.

## History

James Gosling, Mike Sheridan, and Patrick Naughton initiated the Java language project in June 1991.(no content)Java was originally designed for interactive television, but it was too advanced for the digital cable television industry at the time. The language was initially called Oak after an oak tree that stood outside Gosling's office. Later the project went by the name Green and was finally renamed Java, from Java coffee, a type of coffee from Indonesia.(no content)Sun Microsystems released the first public implementation as Java 1.0 in 1996.

## Key Features and Design

One design goal of Java is portability, which means that programs written for the Java platform must run similarly on any combination of hardware and operating system with adequate run time support. This is achieved by compiling the Java language code to an intermediate representation called Java bytecode, instead of directly to architecture-specific machine code.(no content)One of the ideas behind Java's automatic memory management model is that programmers can be spared the burden of having to perform manual memory management.

## Popularity

According to a study, C, Python, and Java were the most commonly used programming languages in 2021.

Web search results for query: "Visitor design pattern"

Links: [{"title":"Visitor pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visitor_pattern"},{"title":"Single-serving visitor pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-serving_visitor_pattern"},{"title":"Talk:Visitor pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Visitor_pattern"},{"title":"File:Visitor design pattern.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Visitor_design_pattern.svg"},{"title":"Talk:Single-serving visitor pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Single-serving_visitor_pattern"},{"title":"Design Patterns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_Patterns_(book)"},{"title":"Decorator pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decorator_pattern"},{"title":"Template:Design patterns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Design_patterns"},{"title":"Visitor (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visitors"},{"title":"Interceptor pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interceptor_pattern"}]

Here's what I found about the Visitor design pattern:

## Overview

A visitor pattern is a software design pattern that separates the algorithm from the object structure.(no content)Because of this separation, new operations can be added to existing object structures without modifying the structures.

## Key Characteristics

The Visitor design pattern is one of the twenty-three Gang of Four design patterns.(no content)In essence, the visitor allows adding new virtual functions to a family of classes, without modifying the classes. Instead, a visitor class is created that implements all of the appropriate specializations of the virtual function.

## How It Works

The visitor declares a visit method, which takes the element as an argument, for each class of element. Concrete visitors are derived from the visitor class and implement these visit methods, each of which implements part of the algorithm operating on the object structure.(no content)The element declares an accept method to accept a visitor, taking the visitor as an argument. Concrete elements, derived from the element class, implement the accept method. In its simplest form, this is no more than a call to the visitor's visit method.

## Drawbacks

A drawback to this pattern, however, is that it makes extensions to the class hierarchy more difficult, as new classes typically require a new visit method to be added to each visitor.

The Visitor pattern is particularly useful when you need to perform many different operations on complex object structures without having to modify the original classes.

Concrete visitors are derived from the visitor class and implement these visit methods, each of which implements part of the algorithm operating on the object structure.(no content)The element declares an accept method to accept a visitor, taking the visitor as an argument. Concrete elements, derived from the element class, implement the accept method. In its simplest form, this is no more than a call to the visitor's visit method.

## Drawbacks

A drawback to this pattern, however, is that it makes extensions to the class hierarchy more difficult, as new classes typically require a new visit method to be added to each visitor.

The Visitor pattern is particularly useful when you need to perform many different operations on complex object structures without having to modify the original classes.

Links: [{"title":"Inheritance (object-oriented programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inheritance_(object-oriented_programming)"},{"title":"Composition over inheritance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composition_over_inheritance"},{"title":"Talk:Inheritance (object-oriented programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Inheritance_(object-oriented_programming)"},{"title":"Class-based programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Class-based_programming"},{"title":"Class hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Class_hierarchy"},{"title":"Multiple inheritance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_inheritance"},{"title":"Prototype-based programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prototype-based_programming"},{"title":"Object-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Common Lisp Object System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Lisp_Object_System"},{"title":"Trait (computer programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trait_(computer_programming)"}]

Here's what I found about inheritance in object-oriented programming:

## Overview

In object-oriented programming, inheritance is the mechanism of basing an object or class upon another object (prototype-based inheritance) or class (class-based inheritance), retaining similar implementation.(no content)Inheritance is used to co-relate two or more classes to each other.

## Key Benefits

Inheritance allows programmers to create classes that are built upon existing classes, to specify a new implementation while maintaining the same behaviors (realizing an interface), to reuse code and to independently extend original software via public classes and interfaces.

## How It Works in Class-Based Languages

In most class-based object-oriented languages like C++, an object created through inheritance, a "child object", acquires all the properties and behaviors of the "parent object", with the exception of: constructors, destructors, overloaded operators and friend functions of the base class.

## Method Overriding

Many object-oriented programming languages permit a class or object to replace the implementation of an aspect—typically a behavior—that it has inherited. This process is called overriding.

## Alternative Approaches

In object-oriented programming, composition over inheritance is a common design pattern that tries to achieve code reuse without requiring inheritance. This approach has gained popularity because implementation inheritance has been controversial among programmers and theoreticians of object-oriented programming since at least the 1990s. Among the critics are the authors of Design Patterns, who advocate instead for interface inheritance, and favor composition over inheritance.

Web search results for query: "Encapsulation object oriented"

Links: [{"title":"Encapsulation (computer programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encapsulation_(computer_programming)"},{"title":"Data encapsulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_encapsulation"},{"title":"Information hiding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_hiding"},{"title":"Object-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Message passing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_(object-oriented_programming)"},{"title":"Design Patterns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_Patterns:_Elements_of_Reusable_Object-Oriented_Software"},{"title":"Object composition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composition_(object-oriented_programming)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about encapsulation in object-oriented programming:

## Definition and Purpose

Encapsulation is a technique that encourages decoupling.(no content)In object-oriented programming languages, encapsulation refers to a language mechanism for restricting direct access to some of the object's components and a language construct that facilitates the bundling of data with the methods (or other functions) operating on those data.

## Key Benefits

Encapsulation prevents external code from being concerned with the internal workings of an object and allows developers to present a consistent interface that is independent of its internal implementation.(no content)Hiding the internals of the object protects its integrity by preventing users from setting the internal data of the component into an invalid or inconsistent state. Additionally, encapsulation can reduce system complexity, and thus increase robustness, by allowing the developer to limit the interdependencies between software components.

## Implementation in OOP

The features of encapsulation are supported using classes in most object-oriented languages.(no content)Some languages like Smalltalk and Ruby only allow access via object methods, but most others (e.g., C++, C#, Delphi or Java) offer the programmer some control over what is hidden, typically via keywords like public and private.

## Core Concepts

Information hiding and encapsulation can refer to several related concepts: Cohesion, keeping related fields and methods together. A field (a.k.a. attribute or property) contains information (a.k.a. state) as a variable. A method (a.k.a. function or action) defines behavior via logic code. Decoupling, organizing code so that only certain parts of the data are used by related functions. Decoupling makes it easier to change how an object works on the inside without affecting other parts of the codebase, such as in code refactoring.

Links: [{"title":"Encapsulation (computer programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encapsulation_(computer_programming)"},{"title":"Data encapsulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_encapsulation"},{"title":"Information hiding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_hiding"},{"title":"Object-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Message passing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_(object-oriented_programming)"},{"title":"Design Patterns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_Patterns:_Elements_of_Reusable_Object-Oriented_Software"},{"title":"Object composition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composition_(object-oriented_programming)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about encapsulation in object-oriented programming:

## Definition and Purpose

Encapsulation is a technique that encourages decoupling.(no content)In object-oriented programming languages, encapsulation refers to a language mechanism for restricting direct access to some of the object's components and a language construct that facilitates the bundling of data with the methods (or other functions) operating on those data.

## Key Benefits

Encapsulation prevents external code from being concerned with the internal workings of an object and allows developers to present a consistent interface that is independent of its internal implementation.(no content)Hiding the internals of the object protects its integrity by preventing users from setting the internal data of the component into an invalid or inconsistent state. Additionally, encapsulation can reduce system complexity, and thus increase robustness, by allowing the developer to limit the interdependencies between software components.

## Implementation in OOP

The features of encapsulation are supported using classes in most object-oriented languages.(no content)Some languages like Smalltalk and Ruby only allow access via object methods, but most others (e.g., C++, C#, Delphi or Java) offer the programmer some control over what is hidden, typically via keywords like public and private.

## Core Concepts

Information hiding and encapsulation can refer to several related concepts: Cohesion, keeping related fields and methods together. A field (a.k.a. attribute or property) contains information (a.k.a. state) as a variable. A method (a.k.a. function or action) defines behavior via logic code. Decoupling, organizing code so that only certain parts of the data are used by related functions. Decoupling makes it easier to change how an object works on the inside without affecting other parts of the codebase, such as in code refactoring.

Here are the search results for "Program verification formal methods":

## Overview

Formal methods are mathematically rigorous techniques for the specification, development, analysis, and verification of software and hardware systems.(no content)The use of formal methods for software and hardware design is motivated by the expectation that performing appropriate mathematical analysis can contribute to the reliability and robustness of a design.

## Key Concepts

Formal verification of software programs involves proving that a program satisfies a formal specification of its behavior.(no content)Formal methods employ a variety of theoretical computer science fundamentals, including logic calculi, formal languages, automata theory, control theory, program semantics, type systems, and type theory.

## Verification Approaches

Subareas of formal verification include deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods. Additionally, model checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification, typically associated with hardware or software systems where the specification contains liveness requirements as well as safety requirements.

## Applications

Formal methods are most likely to be applied to safety-critical or security-critical software and systems, such as avionics software.(no content)For sequential software, examples of formal methods include the B-Method, the specification languages used in automated theorem proving, RAISE, and the Z notation.

Links: [{"title":"Semantics (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Formal semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Denotational semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denotational_semantics"},{"title":"Operational semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_semantics"},{"title":"Formal language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_language"},{"title":"Lambda calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambda_calculus"},{"title":"Type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_theory"},{"title":"Programming language specification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programming_language_specification"},{"title":"Syntax and semantics of logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax_and_semantics_of_logic_programming"}]

## Formal Semantics of Programming Languages

I found comprehensive information about formal semantics in programming languages. Here's an overview:

### Definition

In programming language theory, semantics is the rigorous mathematical logic study of the meaning of programming languages.(no content)Semantics assigns computational meaning to valid strings in a programming language syntax.

### Key Approaches

A formal semantics of a programming language is a mathematical model of how it works. Its goal is to help computer scientists understand, analyze, and verify program behavior.

The main approaches include:

1. **Denotational Semantics**: Denotational semantics is an approach of formalizing the meanings of programming languages by constructing mathematical objects (called denotations) that describe the meanings of expressions.

2. **Operational Semantics**: Operational semantics is a category of formal programming language semantics in which certain desired properties of a program, such as correctness, safety or security, are verified by constructing proofs from logical statements about its execution and procedures.

3. **Axiomatic Semantics**: Axiomatic semantics gives meaning to phrases by describing the axioms that apply to them. Axiomatic semantics makes no distinction between a phrase's meaning and the logical formulas that describe it.

### Benefits

Formal semantics enable mathematical proofs of program correctness and facilitate the design of type systems, and proofs about the soundness of those type systems.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Hoare logic and program correctness:

## Overview

Hoare logic is a specific formal system for reasoning rigorously about the correctness of computer programs. It uses axiomatic techniques to define programming language semantics and argue about the correctness of programs through assertions known as Hoare triples.(no content)Hoare logic is an axiomatic basis for verifying program correctness, developed by computer scientist Tony Hoare.

## Types of Correctness

Hoare logic distinguishes between two key notions of correctness:

- **Partial Correctness**: Partial correctness requires that if an answer is returned it will be correct, whereas total correctness additionally requires that an answer is eventually returned, i.e. the algorithm terminates.

- **Total Correctness**: To prove a program's total correctness, it is sufficient to prove its partial correctness, and its termination.

## Key Mechanisms

Using standard Hoare logic, only partial correctness can be proven. Total correctness additionally requires termination, which can be proven separately or with an extended version of the While rule.(no content)In formal program verification, particularly the Floyd-Hoare approach, loop invariants are expressed by formal predicate logic and used to prove properties of loops and by extension algorithms that employ loops (usually correctness properties).

## Extensions

Separation logic is an extension of Hoare logic, a way of reasoning about programs. This extension has proven useful for reasoning about programs with pointers and concurrent systems.

Links: [{"title":"Hoare logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoare_logic"},{"title":"Tony Hoare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Hoare"},{"title":"Interference freedom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interference_freedom"},{"title":"Talk:Hoare logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Hoare_logic"},{"title":"Correctness (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_correctness"},{"title":"Loop invariant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loop_invariant"},{"title":"Predicate transformer semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predicate_transformer_semantics"},{"title":"Separation logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_logic"},{"title":"Talk:ANSI/ISO C Specification Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:ANSI/ISO_C_Specification_Language"},{"title":"Loop variant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loop_variant"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Hoare logic and program correctness:

## Overview

Hoare logic is a specific formal system for reasoning rigorously about the correctness of computer programs. It uses axiomatic techniques to define programming language semantics and argue about the correctness of programs through assertions known as Hoare triples.(no content)Hoare logic is an axiomatic basis for verifying program correctness, developed by computer scientist Tony Hoare.

## Types of Correctness

Hoare logic distinguishes between two key notions of correctness:

- **Partial Correctness**: Partial correctness requires that if an answer is returned it will be correct, whereas total correctness additionally requires that an answer is eventually returned, i.e. the algorithm terminates.

- **Total Correctness**: To prove a program's total correctness, it is sufficient to prove its partial correctness, and its termination.

## Key Mechanisms

Using standard Hoare logic, only partial correctness can be proven. Total correctness additionally requires termination, which can be proven separately or with an extended version of the While rule.(no content)In formal program verification, particularly the Floyd-Hoare approach, loop invariants are expressed by formal predicate logic and used to prove properties of loops and by extension algorithms that employ loops (usually correctness properties).

## Extensions

Separation logic is an extension of Hoare logic, a way of reasoning about programs. This extension has proven useful for reasoning about programs with pointers and concurrent systems.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Local reasoning for Java". Here's a summary of what was done:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes new methodology)

**Key Findings:**

The paper develops novel formal verification techniques for Java by extending separation logic with concepts tailored for object-oriented programming. The analysis identified 8 major triples:

**Uses (existing work/concepts):**
1. **Separation logic** - The foundational formal reasoning approach being adapted
2. **Java (programming language)** - The target language for verification
3. **Abstract data type** - Core modularity concept addressed
4. **Object-oriented programming** - The programming paradigm being supported
5. **Encapsulation (computer programming)** - Key modularity challenge solved with abstract predicates
6. **Inheritance (object-oriented programming)** - Second modularity issue addressed with abstract predicate families
7. **Visitor pattern** - Design pattern used as verification example

**Proposes (novel contributions):**
8. **Formal verification** - Extensions and adaptations of formal verification methods specifically for Java's object-oriented features

All triples have been validated with correct Wikipedia URLs and the output file is now ready for use.

Sources:
- [Separation logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_logic)
- [Java (programming language)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language))
- [Abstract data type](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_data_type)
- [Object-oriented programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming)
- [Encapsulation (computer programming)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encapsulation_(computer_programming))
- [Inheritance (object-oriented programming)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inheritance_(object-oriented_programming))
- [Visitor pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visitor_pattern)
- [Formal verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)
